As we all know, the European and American Art Nouveau school of the
late ni=
neteenth century was much based on the art disseminated from a
recently tra=
de opened Japan.  I collect old sterling and coin silver,
generally pre-185=
0, but am open to picking up a later piece now and
then if it has nice hand=
work (as opposed to the more typical punch
press garp).  I just landed this=
 small (5 inch) Victorian sugar sifter
ladle by Walter and John Barnard of =
London.  The pierced and hand
engraved theme is ginko, I believe, very Japa=
nese in flavor and not
typical of most occidental Art Nouveau (usually lean=
ed more toward
acanthus).  While not up to Japanese standards, the work her=
e isn't
all that bad, and the piece was in my price range (cheep! cheep!
ch=
eep!).  Note that much of western-made Japanese-style Art Nouveau
metal wor=
k, particularly mixed metal, generally costs much more than
the equivalent =
type (and much superior quality) authentic Japanese
work (well, IMO).
